putting on my PM that codes hat, (versus my coder that PMs hat) -- I've found that many times things start to fly off the hinges when we dev's forget that there is a timeline and strive for the most elegant/perfect solution for a given launch.  Oft times, what gets forgotten as that there needs to be a plan for a post-launch settle-in/clean-up period where you go back and finesse/refactor some areas to bring the code up to a more craftsmen-type level.  You need to find a balance of elegant solutions and still get something *done* at the end of the day. :wq!

i'll tell you what really winds me up when trying to build something. so many of my projects run into roadblocks because of lack of documentation, or sub standard documentation. for instance django-syncr. i've got it working and its brilliant. but the project maintainer has taken to documenting changes needed to the svn on his blog, cos he hasn't got time to keep the google code up to date. and the zip on the site is even firther out of date.
